title: Lebesgue Measure
description: Lebesgue measure extends the notion of length/area/volume to a rich class of sets, enabling the powerful Lebesgue integral that revolutionized analysis.

meta.author: Henri Lebesgue (1901)
originalContributions: Comparison with Jordan measure, non-measurable sets

overview.historicalContext: Lebesgue introduced his measure and integral in his 1901 thesis, revolutionizing analysis. Unlike the Riemann integral, the Lebesgue integral handles limits more gracefully, enabling powerful theorems like dominated convergence.
overview.problemStatement:
**Lebesgue Measure**: There exists a complete, translation-invariant measure mu on R^n such that:
- mu([a,b]) = b - a for intervals
- mu is countably additive on disjoint measurable sets
- The measurable sets form a sigma-algebra containing all Borel sets
overview.proofStrategy: Construct Lebesgue outer measure using infima of covering collections of intervals. Define measurable sets using Caratheodory's criterion. Verify the measure has the required properties.
keyInsights: Lebesgue measure extends 'length' far beyond intervals
Not all sets are measurable (Vitali set construction)
The Lebesgue integral is more powerful than Riemann's
Foundation for probability theory and modern analysis

sections.title: Outer Measure Construction
sections.summary: Building measure via coverings by intervals.

conclusion.summary: Lebesgue measure is the foundation of modern analysis and probability. It provides the right notion of 'size' for doing integration theory in full generality.
conclusion.implications: Applications include probability theory, functional analysis, harmonic analysis, and PDEs. The Lebesgue integral's limit theorems are essential throughout mathematics.
openQuestions: What is the structure of non-measurable sets?
How does Lebesgue measure generalize to infinite dimensions?
What are the connections to fractal dimension?
